content.description: Hard-ish start with a high left crimp and a right hand pinch on the arete followed by a big move to a sloping ledge then leads to easy, quality rock above for a tall top-out. A much harder lower left variation is possible.
content.location:
Take the same trail for

Tribe

and look to your right for some tall boulders right off the road. Problem is easy to spot.

content.description: This overhanging boulder has a scale-like appearance and holds one of the better climbs I've ever tried.  Starts with a low left hand edge and a higher right hand in a slat.  Top-out will keep your attention.

A north-facing overhang is split by a crack with a couple openings for finger locks. Stand on the slab below, lock those digits and get high feet on the glassiest granite I've ever seen. Stair down the lip and get it!

Trying to launch from that glass is like trying to ice skate with roller blades.
content.location: One small ridge before Ellis Spring and after the road turns to dirt, look uphill for some of the largest boulders on the hill. This climb is on a trail on the second boulder. Faces North.

content.description: Technical, thin slab with really one hard move: stand on a dime edge and do a one-legged squat with hardly a dime to hold on to.  Start moves are fun and the finish is slightly insecure.
content.location:
Facing

Tribe

, look right for a boulder with a diagonal seam crack.

content.description: Stand start matched on a nice crimp edge and use more crimps and to gain the arete. Short lived but a great opening sequence.
Sit start on a good rail and either fire to a bread loaf pinch or toss out left to a side-pull in the crack then to the bread loaf. The former is harder. From there, easy climbing on jugs to the top.
content.location:
You'll see this climb as you approach

Stay Glassy

... same boulder.

content.description: Hard stand start by hopping off a foot rail and sticking a bad sloper.  From there, a few powerful moves to the jugs above.  Start would be made easier with height or by standing on pads.
content.location: Same face as Stay Glassy, just to the right on an overhanging corner.

content.description:
This large boulder, resembling a fractured glacier, stands tall and is plainly visible from the road. Deep Freeze starts on obvious holds and moves up the light colored rock to a low-percentage rail then to small crimps to the top.  The rock quality is perfection and the crux is near the top.

Hard sit start is possible.

Name comes from a snowstorm that hit the night before the send and into that morning.
content.location:
Continue past the main boulders and look for a large rock right off the road.  Past that is a grove of trees and past that is a cluster of boulders where it's located. Look for the top half of the climb from the road.  A good trail exists if you can find it.

32.8427 x -116.6393

content.description: On a large boulder resembling a tooth, Cuspid Slab starts on two good holds and follows a very delicate sequence up and right to a small undercling before the very juggy top-out. This climb is very good and the sequence is desperate, utilizing two thumb-presses, simultaneously. (at least for me)
content.location: From Stay Glassy, follow the drainage to the northeast.  Boulder is very obvious... look for the big tooth.

content.description: Reach high for the start and solve the hard one to two move crux before securing the top hold. Figuring out the crux is half the fun and will feel harder until it unlocks. Definitely a fun climb for the circuit.
content.location:
First big slab boulder on your right as you approach

Deep Freeze

.

content.description:
High step onto a shelf and find miniscule edges and a high foot to reach better holds. Feels hard until everything comes together. Uniquely fun slabbin'. Specific grade is more like 5.10b/c.

Another climb for volume is just to the left of this one, starting on thin edges and securing a high right foot.  10c/d
content.location:
As you walk up the trail from the road to

Deep Freeze

, you'll see two sizeable boulders with blank looking faces. This climb is on the second boulder, going uphill. Faces south.
